questions.text: A 1-year-old boy, previously healthy until five months ago, presents with a three-hour history of severe swelling and tenderness of hands and feet. The family history is significant for an older brother who had transfusion-dependent anaemia and died of pneumococcal sepsis at the age of 6. Which haemoglobin molecule composition protected him from developing symptoms until recently?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) α2γ2

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given scenario is most likely suggestive of sickle cell anaemia. This child did not present with the disease earlier because of the presence of fetal haemoglobin (HbF) containing α2γ2
  • HbF inhibits the polymerisation of HbS more effectively than HbA, so infants with sickle cell disease typically remain asymptomatic until 5 or 6 months of age when HbF levels naturally decline.
  • In some individuals, higher levels of HbF persist, a condition known as hereditary persistence of fetal haemoglobin, which makes sickle cell disease less severe.

 

α2β2 & α2δ2 are variants of normal adult haemoglobin present in the circulation (Options B &C)

Normal adult red cells contain

  • HbA/Adult Hemoglobin A -α2β2 [constitute 95% and above of all Hb]
  • HbA2/Hemoglobin A2 -α2δ2 [constitutes <3%]
  • HbF/Fetal hemoglobin- α2γ2.

 

Fetal hemoglobin is the major hemoglobin in fetal RBCs during gestation and constitutes 60 to 80 percent of total hemoglobin in the full-term newborn. By approximately 6 to 12 months of age, Hb F is almost completely replaced by adult hemoglobin.

 

ζ2ε2 (Hb Gower-1) and α2ε2 (Hb Gower-2) are hemoglobin chins seen in the embryonal period (Option D).

questions.text:
Which of the following points best describes the pathogenesis of sickle cell disease (SCD)?

Select all that apply.

 


	Nonsense point mutation in 6th position of β-globin chain
	Mutation promotes the polymerization of oxygenated hemoglobin
	Glutamic acid is changed to valine at the 6th position of β-globin chain
	Presence of HbF and HbS is protective against SCD.
	Patients heterozygous for HbS have more severe diseases than homozygous HbS.
	Individuals with coexistent α-thalassemia have less severe disease.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) C, D, and F

 

Explanation:

 

  • Sickle cell disease is a hemoglobinopathy caused by a missense point mutation in the 6th position of the β-globin chain
  • This replaces the amino acid glutamine with valine which promotes the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin.
  • Heterozygous patients (HbAS) are said to have sickle cell trait where about 40% of the hemoglobin is HbS and the rest is HbA, which interferes with HbS polymerization.
  • Therefore they have less severe disease than their homozygous counterparts who have more HbS.
  • HbF inhibits HbS polymerization more effectively than HbA, keeping infants with sickle cell disease asymptomatic until 5-6 months when HbF levels decline.
  • Metabolically active intracellular parasites consume oxygen and decrease intracellular pH, promoting sickling of HbAS red cells, which are then rapidly cleared by splenic and hepatic phagocytes, reducing parasite loads.
  • In individuals with coexistent α-thalassemia, reduced Hb synthesis results in milder disease.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not lead to sickling of RBCs in patients with sickle cell disease?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Increased pH

Explanation:

Among the given options, increased pH/alkalosis does not lead to sickling, but rather decreased pH or acidosis.

Factors affecting sickling:

  1. Dehydration - Higher HbS concentrations and increased MCHC due to intracellular dehydration enhance the likelihood of HbS aggregation and polymerization during deoxygenation, facilitating sickling.
  2. Hypoxia - Hypoxia induces sickling of cells
  3. Less pH (acidic environment): A decrease in pH reduces hemoglobin's oxygen affinity, increasing deoxygenated HbS and enhancing the tendency for sickling.
  4. Amount of HbS: Homozygous>heterozygous
  5. Interaction of HbS with the other types of hemoglobin: HbSC> HbSA/HbSA2 > HbSF (Fetal hemoglobin has more affinity towards oxygen, thus reducing sickling)

questions.text: A 28-year-old man who has received blood transfusions on some occasions and has experienced severe pain in his hands and legs came to follow up. He is currently fine with no complaints and has been receiving treatment that has increased his HbF levels for the past 5 years. Which of the following would be seen in the peripheral smear of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Howell Jolly bodies

Explanation:

  • The peripheral smear of this patient would show Howell-Jolly bodies.They are basophilic nuclear remnants present in the RBC seen in conditions causing asplenia.
  • Given the patient's age and history of blood transfusions, severe pain episodes in his hands and legs, and treatment aimed at increasing HbF (fetal hemoglobin) levels, it is likely that he has sickle cell disease along with asplenia due to recurrent vaso-occlusive crises.
  • There is massive splenomegaly in early childhood due to sequestration.
  • Repeated microvascular infarcts due to chronic erythrostasis and fibrosis causes it to atrophy and shrink over the years resulting in asplenia.
  • This process is called autosplenectomy.
  • Complications of asplenia:
    • Susceptible to severe infections and sepsis by organisms:

 

Encapsulated bacteria
  • Pneumococcus
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Bordetella holmesii

Bloodborne parasites
  • Babesia spp
  • Plasmodium spp

 

  • Preventive measures include vaccination against S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis, influenza, and SARS-CoV-2; and prophylactic antibiotics.

Heinz bodies are denatured and precipitated hemoglobin found inside RBCs seen in G6PD deficiency. Bite cells are formed due to removal of Heinz bodies by splenic macrophages (Options A and B).

Spherocytes are small, spherical RBCs without central pallor seen mainly in AIHA and hereditary spherocytosis (Option D).

questions.text:
Match the complications of sickle cell disease (SCD) with their corresponding crises:


	
		
			
			Complications
			
			
			Crises
			
		
		
			
			1. Acute chest syndrome
			
			
			A. Vaso-occlusive crises
			
		
		
			
			2. Parvovirus B19 infection
			
			
			B. Aplastic crises
			
		
		
			
			3. Splenic enlargement
			
			
			C. Sequestration crisis
			
		
		
			
			4. Splenic fibrosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A

 

Explanation:

 

Vaso-occlusive crises include:

1. Bone crises: Common in children, presenting as hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis.

2. Acute chest syndrome: Affecting the lungs, it presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates, potentially leading to life-threatening hypoxemia.

3. Renal papillary necrosis: Causes abrupt onset gross hematuria due to microvascular occlusion in the kidney.

4. Cerebrovascular accidents: Occlusions in the brain result in stroke.

5. Priapism: Painful, prolonged erection due to blood vessel occlusion in the penis.

6. Autosplenectomy - Repeated infarctions cause atrophy of the spleen.

 

Aplastic crisis in SCD -

Aplastic crises occur when red cell progenitors are infected by parvovirus B19, leading to a temporary halt in erythropoiesis and a sudden exacerbation of anemia.

 

Sequestration crisis in SCD -

Sequestration crisis affect children with intact spleens, characterized by significant trapping of sickled red cells, resulting in swift splenic enlargement, hypovolemia, and occasionally shock.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents to her primary care physician with complaints of fatigue, pallor, and jaundice. Peripheral smear showed sickling of RBCs. What is the most likely electrophoretic pattern seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) B

Explanation:

The patient's clinical presentation with fatigue, pallor, jaundice, and the presence of sickle cells on peripheral blood smear are consistent with sickle cell anemia. The electrophoretic pattern seen in this patient would be B.

  • Electrophoresis is a type of chromatography technique and one of the tests used to detect Hb variants.
  • Principle: Movement of different hemoglobin based on electric charge and solubility in a medium
  • To identify hemoglobin variants, different pH and mediums are used:
    • Cellulose acetate electrophoresis at alkaline pH (8.4)
    • Citrate agar at acidic pH(6.0–6.2)
  • The gold standard for diagnosis of different hemoglobinopathies is HPLC (high-performance liquid chromatography)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the different types of thalassemia is correct?


	Thalassemia major - mutations in both alleles of the HBB gene - impaired production of beta-globin chains.
	Beta-thalassemia trait - mutations in one allele of the HBB gene - reduced beta-globin chain synthesis.
	Alpha-thalassemia trait - deletions in one or more alpha-globin genes - decreased production of alpha-globin chains.
	Thalassemia intermedia - mutations affecting both alpha and beta-globin genes - severe anemia requiring regular blood transfusions
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, and 3

 

Explanation:

Statements 1, 2, & 3 are correct. Statement 4 is wrong as thalassemia intermedia does not require regular blood transfusions.

  • A thalassemia is a group of inherited blood disorders characterized by abnormal hemoglobin production, leading to anemia.
  • Genetic defects in thalassemia involve mutations, insertions, or deletions in the genes responsible for producing hemoglobin chains
  • This results in either decreased or absent production of alpha or beta-globin chains.
  • These defects are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning an individual must inherit mutated alleles from both parents to manifest the disorder.
  • There are two main types: alpha-thalassemia and beta-thalassemia.

1. Alpha-thalassemia: Resulting from deletions or mutations in the alpha-globin genes located on chromosome 16.

2. Beta-thalassemia: Arising from mutations in the beta-globin gene located on chromosome 11. Subtypes include:

  • Beta-thalassemia minor (trait): Reduced beta-globin chain production due to mutations in one allele of the HBB gene.
  • Beta-thalassemia major: Mutations in both alleles of the HBB gene, leading to severe anemia requiring lifelong transfusions and treatment.
  • Thalassemia intermedia: Milder variants and unusual forms of β-thalassemia, also include alpha globin defects in some cases. But the cases does not require regular blood transfusions

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with fatigue, jaundice, and splenomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal microcytic hypochromic anemia with increased levels of serum iron and ferritin. Further genetic analysis reveals a mutation in the HBB gene. Upon histopathological examination of the bone marrow, there is evidence of erythroid hyperplasia with ineffective erythropoiesis. Which mutation in the HBB gene is most likely responsible for the patient's presentation?

choices.text: Substitution of cytosine for guanine at position 8 in the promoter region of the HBB gene.
Substitution of one nucleotide at position +8 in the coding region of the HBB gene.
Splicing mutation resulting in the removal of intervening sequence-IVS1-5 G-> C in the HBB gene.
Insertion of a nucleotide at position 54 in the coding region of the HBB gene

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Splicing mutation resulting in the removal of intervening sequence-IVS1-5 G-> C in the HBB gene.

Explanation:

Among the given options, Splicing mutation resulting in the removal of intervening sequence-IVS1-5 G-> C in the HBB gene leads to β-thalassemia: This mutation affects the splicing process by altering the consensus splice site, leading to aberrant splicing and abnormal mRNA transcripts, contributing to β-thalassemia.

  • Beta-thalassemia mutations are diverse and can occur throughout the HBB gene, which encodes the beta-globin subunit of hemoglobin.
  • These mutations can affect various aspects of beta-globin production, including transcription, splicing, mRNA stability, and translation.
  • Common types of mutations include point mutations, small insertions or deletions, large deletions, and rearrangements within the HBB gene.
  • These mutations disrupt normal hemoglobin synthesis, leading to reduced or absent beta-globin production and the characteristic clinical features of beta-thalassemia.

Substitution of cytosine for guanine at position 8 in the promoter region of the HBB gene (Option A): Substitution of cytosine for guanine at position -28 in the promoter region of the HBB gene affects the promoter region of the HBB gene, potentially altering the binding of transcription factors and reducing the expression of the β-globin gene, leading to β-thalassemia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with beta-thalassemia major presents to the cardiology clinic with complaints of increasing shortness of breath on exertion and swelling in her ankles. She has been undergoing regular blood transfusions since childhood. She dies after a few days of hospitalization. What is the most common condition leading to her death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Heart failure

Explanation:

The above scenario of heart failure is the most common cause of death in beta-thalassemia major.

  • Cardiac disease resulting from progressive iron overload and secondary hemochromatosis is the most common cause of death in patients with beta-thalassemia major
  • They must be treated with iron chelators to prevent this complication.
  • Other complications include growth retardation, splenomegaly, leg ulcers, hepatic disease, lung disease/pulmonary hypertension, thromboembolism, endocrinopathies, and bone disease.
  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the only therapy offering a cure in these patients.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic for routine prenatal care. She has no significant past medical history. Her initial lab work reveals a microcytic, hypochromic anemia. Which of the following statements is most accurate in differentiating between iron deficiency anemia (IDA) and beta-thalassemia minor in this patient?

choices.text: RDW is typically elevated in IDA compared to beta-thalassemia minor
RDW is typically lower in IDA compared to beta-thalassemia minor
Mentzer index is >13 in beta-thalassemia minor
RDW is typically normal in both IDA and beta-thalassemia minor

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) RDW is typically elevated in IDA compared to beta-thalassemia minor

Explanation:

RDW is significantly higher in patients with IDA compared to those with beta-thalassemia minor or coexistent IDA and beta-thalassemia traits.

  • This is because in IDA, the erythropoiesis process is disrupted, leading to a more varied size of red blood cells and thus an increased RDW.
  • In contrast, RDW tends to be lower in beta-thalassemia minor as most cells are just microcytic and hypochromic due to uniformly reduced hemoglobin synthesis.
  • The Mentzer index, which is the MCV divided by the RBC count, is more useful in distinguishing between IDA and beta-thalassemia minor, with a lower Mentzer index (<13) indicating beta-thalassemia minor.
  • Therefore, an elevated RDW favors a diagnosis of IDA over beta-thalassemia minor in this patient with microcytic, hypochromic anemia.
  • Confirmatory testing with hemoglobin electrophoresis to detect elevated HbA2 levels (>3.5%) is required to diagnose beta-thalassemia minor.

questions.text:
A hematologist is reviewing the peripheral blood smears of three patients diagnosed with different types of thalassemia.

Patient A has severe anemia, target cells, and nucleated red blood cells (NRBCs).

Patient B has mild anemia with microcytosis and hypochromia but no NRBCs.

Patient C has mild anemia with microcytosis and hypochromia but also shows a small number of NRBCs and some hemoglobin H inclusions.

Based on the peripheral smear findings, which of the following correctly matches the patients with their thalassemia types?

choices.text: Patient A: β-thalassemia major, Patient B: β-thalassemia minor, Patient C: α-thalassemia
Patient A: β-thalassemia minor, Patient B: α-thalassemia, Patient C: β-thalassemia major
Patient A: α-thalassemia, Patient B: β-thalassemia minor, Patient C: β-thalassemia major
Patient A: β-thalassemia major, Patient B: α-thalassemia, Patient C: β-thalassemia minor

questions.solution:
The peripheral smear findings can help distinguish between different types of thalassemia:

  • β-thalassemia major (Patient A): This condition is characterized by severe anemia. The peripheral smear typically shows significant abnormalities, including target cells, nucleated red blood cells (NRBCs), microcytosis, hypochromia, and anisopoikilocytosis. These findings are consistent with the severe hemolytic anemia and ineffective erythropoiesis seen in β-thalassemia major.
  • β-thalassemia minor (Patient B): This condition usually presents with mild anemia. The peripheral smear shows microcytosis and hypochromia but generally lacks significant numbers of NRBCs.
  • α-thalassemia (Patient C): This condition can vary in severity. The peripheral smear of a patient with α-thalassemia trait may show mild anemia, microcytosis, and hypochromia. In cases of HbH disease (a form of α-thalassemia), the smear can also show NRBCs and hemoglobin H inclusions (golf ball cells), which are not seen in β-thalassemia minor.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most consistent with β thalassemia major when compared to β thalassemia minor?

choices.text:
Decrease in HbA, slight increase in HbA2, and normal HbF;

HPLC: HbA2: 6%, HbF: 2%

Decrease in HbA, increase in HbA2, and marked increase in HbF;

HPLC: HbA2: 6%, HbF: 90%

Absent HbA, slight increase in HbA2, and moderate increase in HbF;

HPLC: HbA2: 4%, HbF: 20%

Decrease in HbA, normal HbA2, and normal HbF;

HPLC: HbA2: 2%, HbF: 2%

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Decrease in HbA, increase in HbA2, and marked increase in HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 6%, HbF: 90%

Explanation:

β thalassemia major is characterised by decrease in HbA, increase in HbA2, and marked increase in HbF; HPLC: HbA2: 6%, HbF: 90%

  • In β thalassemia major, there is a severe decrease in adult hemoglobin (HbA)
  • Leading to a marked decrease in HbA levels
  • Compensatory elevation of HbF, often exceeding 90%.
  • Additionally, HbA2 levels may be normal or slightly elevated.
  • HbA 0-5%, HbA2- 5%, HbF >90%


 

Decrease in HbA, slight increase in HbA2, and normal HbF;

HPLC: HbA2: 6%, HbF: 2% (Option A): 

  • These findings are more indicative of β thalassemia trait. There is a decrease in the production of adult hemoglobin (HbA),with compensatory elevation of HbA2 and normal HbF levels.

Absent HbA, slight increase in HbA2, and moderate increase in HbF;

HPLC: HbA2: 4%, HbF: 20% (Option C): 

  • This is seen in sickle cell anemia with absent HbA, presence of sickle hemoglobin HbS >75%, HbA2: 4% and HbF: 20%

Decrease in HbA, normal HbA2, and normal HbF;

HPLC: HbA2: 2%, HbF: 2% (Option D): 

  • These findings are more indicative of Sickle cell trait. Here HbA levels are reduced 60-70%, and HbS is present 30%, with normal HbA2 and HbF levels.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is a silent carrier for α-thalassemia (α-/αα) and is concerned about the risk of her child inheriting α-thalassemia. Her partner has the α-thalassemia trait (αα/--). What is the probability that their child will have Hemoglobin H (HbH) disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 25%

Explanation:

This couple will have a 25% chance of their child being affected with Hemoglobin H Disease

The α-globin gene is located on chromosome 16, and each individual has two copies of this gene on each chromosome, for a total of four α-globin genes (αα/αα).

  • Silent Carrier (α-/αα): Has one missing or mutated α-globin gene.
  • α-Thalassemia Trait (αα/-- or α-/α-): Has two missing or mutated α-globin genes.
  • HbH Disease (α-/--): Has three missing or mutated α-globin genes.
  • Hydrops Fetalis ( --/-- ): Has all four α-globin genes missing,incompatible with life.

questions.text: The medical team, aware of the prevalence of genetic disorders in the village decides to implement a screening process using NESTROFT for beta thalassemia. They plan to test the result by observing the solution turning clear by checking the visibility of a black line behind the test and control tubes. Which of the following on Nestrof test would be indicative of a positive result?

choices.text: Black line visible in both tubes
Black line visible in only control tubes
Black line visible in only test tubes
No black line visible in any of the tubes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) black line visible only in the test tubes 

 

Explanation:

A black line visible only in the test tubes containing blood sample mixed with a 0.36 buffered solution is suggestive of a positive Nestrof test.

The Nestrof test, also known as the Naked Eye Single Tube Red Cell Osmotic Fragility Test, is a screening test used to identify carriers of beta thalassemia and sickle cell anemia.

The test is based on the principle that red blood cells (RBCs) from individuals with beta thalassemia have red blood cells that are more fragile and burst more easily in hypotonic solutions

Procedure:

  • Bloood sample is mixed with 0.36% saline solution
  • After incubation, observe the test tube against a black line.
  • Look for the presence or absence of a black line behind the tube.

Interpretation:

  • Positive Test:
    • Black line visible in only the test tube
    • A positive NESTROFT indicates that red cells in the tested sample have undergone lysis in 0.36% buffered saline. Thus a positive NESTROFT indicates increased red cell osmotic fragility.

 

  • Negative Test (Normal Result):
    • No black line visible in any of the test tubes
    • This indicates that the RBCs have remained intact in control as well as test tube.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding warm antibody-mediated autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA)?

choices.text: It is commonly mediated by IgG antibodies active at 37°C.
It can be associated with the intake of drugs like alpha-methyldopa and quinine.
It typically involves the destruction of red blood cells primarily in the liver.
A positive direct Coombs test is often used to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It typically involves the destruction of red blood cells primarily in the liver.

 

Explanation:

The wrong statement regarding warm AIHA is it involves the destruction of red blood cells primarily in the liver, as it is typically seen in the spleen.
